documents.title: that 's everything from eimear
text: thanks so much to eimear for her illuminating responses .
her new novel the lesser bohemians is out now , and is available from the guardian bookshop ; she discusses a girl is a half-formed thing at a guardian book club event on 29 september .
until next time !
casseano99 asks : as a former ( doting ) student of his in trinity , i was intrigued to see your dedication to dr. jarlath killeen in a girl is a half-formed thing .

as an academic primarily focussed on gothic/horror , i was interested in the influence he had on the novel , and whether these genres were deliberate touchpoints in the creation of a girl is a half-formed thing .
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:21pm jarlath and i were at school together and have been friends for years .
but i 'm also interested in the irish gothic tradition and think there 's an argument for placing a girl is a half-formed thing within it .
hollymaya asks : in each of your books the reader is very much bound in the narrator 's mind and body - i wonder , when you write these characters , do you see them ?
do you know what they look like ?

so many writing courses say you have to know the colour of your character 's hair , or their height , what kind of shoes they 'd wear is it about that or is it about being in that character in that moment ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:19pm i do see them but i also try to see out through their eyes in the moment .
how they perceive the world is a rich source of information about who they are .
it 's important to know everything you can about your central characters but it 's not important to tell everything to your reader .
if you understand who these people are , they will also understand who they are and the details can be left in a draft .
toomanywilsons asks : you have n't seen my car-keys , have you ?
they simply must be somewhere guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:17pm did you look behind the microwave ?
fridtjof ryder asks : i have been acting for years and ask a question which bugs me desperately .
do you consider that an actor can infact himself be a creator , himself be an artist ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:16pm well , when i was at drama school all those years ago i certainly thought so .
many actors branch out into other roles in order to give themselves more creative control and the needs of the theatre have changed a lot too .
devised work is increasingly popular and involves far more of the actor than the traditional 'faster , louder ' approach of years ago .
i suppose the truth of it is only to be found in yourself though .

documents.title: 'i 'm a bit sick of the joyce comparisons he and i are not interested in the same things '
text: id9120778 asks : do you get tired of the joyce comparisons ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:13pm i 'm a bit sick of them by now alright .
at the start i was so surprised to see my name appear in the same sentence as his that i did n't consider how complicated that might become .
now , i know .
so i should say that while joyce was hugely influential on the development of some formal and linguistic chutzpah in my writing , the comparisons run out of steam there .
he and i are not interested in the same things .
we are going in opposite directions .
maninchina asks : i was wondering what you did during the time before your book became a success .
what got you through ?
it must have , at times , been very challenging .
was there anything in particular that helped you through what must , for an aspiring writer , have been a tough time ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:10pm sometimes there 's no way through but through .
in all those years of unlovely publishing failure the one thing i held onto was the knowledge that the book was what it had to be .
i did n't know if it was good or not but i did know it was the best i could do .
that 's really the only way to cope with all the rejection and , actually , the only way to cope with the pressure of success as well .
if you know you have made your novel what you want it to be then everything is liveable with .

kristina wilde asks : your narrative voice is very organic - it feels reductive to call it stream of consciousness ' but it does feel like someone is talking naturally and talking to you through the pages .
does writing come forth in bursts as you sit there ( wherever you write ) , or are you the type of person who always carries a notebook for vignettes that you later meld into the book proper ?
also your hair colour is lovely : ) guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:07pm i do n't keep a notebook .

after having two year 's worth of notes stolen before i wrote a girl i 'm inclined to believe that if it 's a good idea i 'll remember it , if it 's a bad idea i 'll forget and not be tempted to try and force it in .
there 's not much bursting though .
writing is a slow plod through failure , one day there 's light , then a little more and on it goes .
thanks for the hair colour comment , i chose it myself !

documents.title: 'i wonder if teaching writers how to solve problems ends up influencing the calibre of the solutions they come up with '
text: c1airea asks : your writing has been described as singular and you seem to have taught yourself .
what 's your line on creative writing courses ?
how did you learn ?
who were your teachers ( in terms of the literary canon ) ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 2:03pm yes , i did teach myself to write but i also use techniques that i learned in my acting training .
a good writer wo n't wed themselves to a particular technique .
form and content are the twin goals and however you get to the point of making them work in concert is more important than any rules you may be taught .
i am cautious about the creative writing course obsession which seems to be gripping the industry at the moment .
obviously i have no direct experience of it so i do n't know what exactly it does for a writer .

i am , however , often reminded of david mamet 's comment about having a fall back , that 'you will always fall back ' and i wonder if teaching writers how to solve problems ends up influencing the calibre of the solutions they come up with .

on the other side , it does no harm to go into the savage world of publishing with a little prior knowledge of what you will encounter there and anything that helps debut novelists get a toe-hold on the ladder is a good thing , as far as i 'm concerned .
getrochelle asks : your books have this gorgeous rhythm and rhyme to them that ( i think ) makes them even better to experience in audio format .
how important to you is having an audio versions of your books available ?
i know you 've narrated both audio books yourself .
how important is it for you that you narrate your own work ?
thanks - from a big eimear mcbride fan who is unable to read with her eyes .
you 're my favourite !
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:59pm i 'm a terrible control freak so there was never any question of letting anyone else narrate the books .
for me , it 's my final word on how they should sound and i am delighted to have had the opportunity to record both of them .
i 'm glad you enjoyed them .
i really enjoyed the process of recording them .
stacey busuttil asks : with the kind of writing style you adopt , i 'm curious as to how you and your publisher go about editing ?
keeping in mind the rhythm and flow of the language involved is it difficult to find the balance between the cadence of the sentences and overall clarity ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:57pm we discussed it on the level of the scene and the overall narrative arc .
because of the rhythmical structures she did n't line edit , beyond occasionally saying 'i have no idea what that sentence means ' which was useful .
i was very fortunate that she was so sensitive to the inextricable connection between form and content and , mostly , left me to it .
ritzcrisps asks : what does your writing day look like , and do you write in silence ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:54pm i 'm mostly at the desk around 9.30 and go on until 5pm with occasional breaks for despair .
sometimes i write in silence , sometimes with music .
it depends on how thorny the language is being on a given day .
the only 'must ' is solitude .

documents.title: 'given my publishing history , i have a high tolerance of humiliation '
text: another sex-in-writing question , this time from siancain : the lesser bohemians contains some wonderfully written sex scenes - what is it like as a fiction writer tackling sex , famously hard to get right on the page ?
was it daunting , or enjoyable to craft ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:51pm i think i 've replied to this one earlier .
getting over your own self-consciousness is important .
i enjoyed it as much as i enjoyed writing everything else but with the knowledge that the consequences of getting it wrong would be humiliating .
happily , given my publishing history , i have a high tolerance of humiliation and so just got on with it .
35 kanyon asks : what tip would give too any male or female who want too write a novel .
would they have too study at university , too get there or would someone have be very good at english just too get that done .
i have alway want too do novel based around a female drug addict somewhere living in leeds , somewhat in the same vain as trainspotting .
what ideas would have for a story like that and how would you get started do you like my idea .
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:49pm i 'm not a creative writing teacher .
i 'm a novelist .
i have no useful pointers beyond advising would-be novelists to sit down and write , then once they 're finished go back with a big red pen and keep doing it until you know you 're done .
whether or not to go to university is down to you .
i did n't , lots of other writers have , but either way , no one is going to solve the central problem of writing a novel for you .
that 's something you either manage to do by yourself or you do n't .
stuffandstuffan asks : what is the best book you 've read this year ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:47pm i think i 've already covered this : anakana !
eddie docherty asks : hi eimear .
i was wondering .
i was wondering about writing style .
gambles .
get it wrong and your book is dead .
so choosing .
choosing is so important .
how do you .
choose , i mean .
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:46pm i do n't choose .
i just write .
do n't be too clever about it all .
use your instinct .
if you 're a writer it will guide you .
if you 're not , then all the choosing in the world wo n't save you .
thethoughtfox asks : i 'm from westport , co mayo .
when you lived in castlebar did you hate people from westport , as is the rule ?
and where did you go for a pint ?
i 'm guessing the humbert .
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:44pm i was a bit of an interloper to castlebar , having only arrived at 14 , so i was n't too aware of the traditional rivalry .
the humbert was n't really the place in those days .
in our late teens our friends and i used to drink at the irish house , later in mccarthy 's .
nowadays more usually at johnny mchale 's .
kurtzscaddy asks : can i ask you out ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:40pm if you are robert deniro in 1979 then the answer is yes .

documents.title: 'if i had self-published girl it would have disappeared without a trace '
text: danholloway asks : if it had n't been for the fabulous people at galley beggar , you might very easily not have landed a publisher .
do you think that if you had self-published , the book would have had anything like the recognition it has so deservedly achieved ?
do you think how nearly a book like yours fell through the cracks should give people cause to stop and think about whether they are taking a big risk by not considering self-published titles ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:38pm the whole landscape around publishing has changed so much in the years since i wrote a girl that it 's hard to say .

thirteen years ago self-publishing was still called 'vanity publishing ' and was pretty much the province of retired sergeant-majors who wanted to write about their saucy escapades in the far east back in the 50s .
that has completely changed now and writers have the possibility of self-publishing into an engaged and receptive audience .

i think it 's still a trickier solution for literary fiction than genre fiction , certainly for any kind of experimental work and i firmly believe that if i had self-published girl it would have disappeared without a trace .
no one knows better than i how lucky i was or how easily i could still be sitting at home with that book in a drawer and no prospect of that situation ever changing .
but i knew it needed a publisher to stand behind it and say they believed in it .
i was fortunate enough to find galley beggar and , happily for unpublished authors , there are now many indie presses out there who are anxious to turn readers attention to more complex work .
self-publishing is an excellent solution but not the best one in every situation .
theloneliestmonk asks : why do you think the modernist legacy of joyce , beckett and flann o ' brien has been so neglected by irish writers ?

there are lots of bows in their direction but very few ( aidan higgins is one exception ) have taken up the linguistic challenges , until you wrote a girl ' guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:34pm i do n't know if that 's the case .
i think irish writers have engaged with that legacy in lots of different ways over the years .

it 's true that social realism has been the public face of irish writing for the last few decades , and 'high ' modernism was somewhat prematurely relegated to history by critics who did not know what it could do next , but within that have been other things going on .
dorothy nelson 's in night 's city , written in the 1980s , is a prime example of an incredibly innovative novel that fell foul of fashion and disappeared as a result .

a girl was just very direct about that influence , even as it was seeking to use those tools to different ends , in a time when no one was looking in that direction , and appeared more surprising as a result .
fourpaws asks : hello eimear , i 've just finished reading your latest novel and thought it was brilliant .
best thing i 've read this year .
i read til 2 in the morning the other night to finish it .
i just could n't go to sleep until i knew the ending .
as a student in late 1980s london the places , the lifestyle , the tone were all instantly recognisable .
i love the way your writing opens out as the story progresses and as the love unfolds and we get to know the protagonists and their names .
it 's like you bring the characters from out of focus to sharply in focus .
i would like to ask if you can explain how you approach your writing .
do you write the book and then create the dialogue afterwards ?
it is so multi-layered can you give some insight into your creative process and how you find your characters ' voices ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:29pm i 'm not sure how to explain this .
everything happens all at once for me .
it took a long time to understand what i was writing about and who i was writing about .
what was clear from early on though was that the reader was going to experience the two voices in different ways .
they are embedded in the voice and experience of the young girl .
they know everything about her and there are no boundaries between the reader and the character .
with the older actor , the reader only experiences him through her eyes .
they see what she sees and hear what she hears .
their knowledge of him and his internal workings are the same as how we all experience other people in life .
our understanding of him is totally reliant on what he says , how he says it and the way he behaves .
for me it was also a game of welding a modernist internal monologue together with the 19th century external monologue and seeing how they influence each other .
the dialogue and exposition were all written at the same time though .
they are inextricable and complete each other .
dumbwit asks : what happens when you disagree with an editor 's suggestions ?
how much input should they have in the work you are trying to create ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:25pm it 's important to listen to an outside voice .
an editor can sometimes see problems an author ca n't .
their solutions may not always be the right ones for the book but their comments can lead you on to other interesting solutions .
how much input they should have depends how much you think you need .
some writers like a lot of back and forth and find it both invigorating and useful .
others prefer minimal contact .
at the end of the day , the author lives with consequences so they have to set the bar .
rossboss asks : hi eimear , what was the last truly brilliant book you 've read ?
one you wanted to start reading again immediately .
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:22pm martin john by anakana schofield .
she is the real thing and that book is a work of genius .
language and form spill over the boundaries while never losing touch with the humanity of central characters .
i do n't know how she does it and i thoroughly recommend it .
read the guardian review of martin john here : martin john by anakana schofield review funny , distressing and complicated read more
adrian kelly asks : at the risk of asking you to overthink it , i 'm wondering about the provenance of your style .
did it come relatively naturally to you ?
to what extent was it willed , worked , wrestled with ?
did you set out writing proper ' english-literary sentences and find old forms constraining ?
do you think you 'll go on writing as you do in the first two books , or is that too becoming an orthodoxy ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:20pm this is , in many ways , an impossible question to answer .
language is something i wrestle with constantly and its inability to be precise pushes me on to try to expand its possibilities .
it 's an agony and delight all in one , and all the time .
i work very hard on it and have never yet been completely satisfied by the result but i keep trying .

both books have a similarity of style but while girl is a journey to destruction which the language reflects , the lesser bohemians is about the possibility of connection to the world and so the language reaches out and begins to connect up as the story progresses .
i do n't have a plan for how i will write in future .
finding out is half the fun .

documents.title: influences on the lesser bohemians ? tindersticks , tarkovsky and tillmans
text: serendipity1994 asks : i was wondering if you get inspired by films , plays or other mediums of art to aid your writing .
if that 's the case which had the most impact ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:15pm writing the lesser bohemians was a very different experience to a girl which really only had literary influences .
with tlb , music was hugely important .
not only did it help me key back into the climate of london in the 1990s , it was also listening to a lot of male singer-songwriters which provided inspiration for writing in a male voice .
you encounter such a different approach to maleness in song-writing and that was invaluable .
for instance the tindersticks ( ii ) album was the basis for the long male monologue both in terms of ideas and atmosphere .
thanks too to nick cave , brett anderson , jarvis cocker and a host of others .
the films of tarkovsky are a source of inspiration too .
his ability to force the viewer 's concentration in any direction he wants was very important .
i also studied an awful lot of photographs .
wolfgang tillmans particularly .
his earlier work for its human vulnerability and his later work for its challenges to form .
porlockhere asks : what question ( s ) are you most hoping people might ask you ?
what do you think freud meant when he said that the irish are not psychoanalyzible ?

guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:12pm perhaps : `` do you think the pressure to meet the requirements of the creative writing industry is having a deleterious effect upon our ability to appreciate fiction that is not symmetrical and to speak about literature in an imperfect , non-synthesized way ? ''
as far as i am aware freud never actually said that but the fact that it is so widely accepted says to me we recognise a grain of truth in it .
i have often thought about the similarity between the stereoty notions of the irish and russian temperaments .
the russians know there is an abyss and stare down into it , the irish also know there is an abyss but prefer to look a little to the left .
this may have some bearing on our use of language and i am all for that .

documents.title: on writing about sex : 'specificity is the most important thing '
text: carlbr0wn asks : writing about sex seems to be something even great writers can stumble over what are your tips ? ?
also , why do you find the transition into female adulthood such a rich topic for fiction ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:07pm for me specificity is the most important thing to cling to when writing about sex .

sex itself is , with a few variations , a pretty standard activity : something goes in somewhere until at least one person is happy , so what can be understood from any description of the physical is pretty limited .
where it gets interesting is exploring the who and why of what 's going on .
then you 're back into the realm of character and that 's everything for me .
regarding the transition to female adulthood , it 's the great moment of change .
the moment when a person stops being reactive and begins to really make the decisions that will shape who they 'll become .
it 's a vulnerable period yet people often do n't understand how vulnerable they were until a long time afterwards , which is sort-of captivating .

additionally , girls on the cusp of becoming women are so weighed down with fraudulent and frequently damaging images and ideas of what a woman should be that they have a whole other layer to cut through before they can get to the truth of themselves and what they want from life .

documents.title: eimear is with us now
text: eimear mcbride has started taking on your questions , beginning with this trio from ciaran quinn : how do you manage to write and stop the mundane aspects of life from getting in the way ?
what direction do you think irish writing as a whole will take in the next few years ?
i just read an article in the guardian where writers gave their best writing tip , what would yours be ?
guardian contributor eimearmcbride 12 september 2016 1:01pm every writer will tell you that discipline is everything .
make a decision to take your writing life seriously and stick to it .
no one will help you do that or thank you for managing to .
it 's all on you .
i think irish writing can go anywhere it wants and it usually does .
the post-boom life is obviously a subject at the moment but , underneath that , the nation 's predilection for secrets is a subject which never goes away .
my best tip is : stop asking for tips and go write your book .

documents.title: post your questions for eimear mcbride
text: when it appeared on a tiny independent press in 2013 after years of rejections , you would n't have pegged eimear mcbride 's a girl is a half-formed thing for major success .
but it went on to win a string of awards including the bailey 's prize , and was adapted into an acclaimed stage play .

this tale of a woman moving from dysfunctional childhood into sexually fraught adulthood was described by anne enright in the guardian as an instant classic ¦ she writes truth-spilling , uncompromising and brilliant prose .

its follow-up , the lesser bohemians , about another young woman exploring adult life , is similarly acclaimed : it is notoriously difficult to write about sex , and mcbride does it better than almost any other contemporary novelist i 've read , wrote lara feigel in the guardian .
with the lesser bohemians out now and ahead of a guardian book club event on 29 september mcbride is joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat , from 1pm on monday 12 september .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
